column2: Marble arch was the state entrance to Buckingham Palace until it was moved. Now it is an entrance to Hyde Park.
Stroll through Hyde Park until you reach Wellington Arch. Hyde Park is the largest park in central London.
Buckingham Palace is the official residence for the English monarchy. It is used for royal hospitality and special ocasions.

Changing the Guard is a famous ceremony where the classic british guards march to change turns. Normally the ceremony starts at 11:30; but it is crowded so arrive early. Make sure to check this webpage https://changing-guard.com/dates-buckingham-palace.html for the calendar.
Westmister Abbey is a Romanesque Abbey Church where coronations and other ceremonies of national significance are held.

After your visit to Westimister Abbey walk towards River Thames where London's main landmarks are Big Ben a famous clock tower and Westmister Palace where the House of Commons and the House of Lords meet.
St Stephen's Tavern is a classic English pub here you can eat an authentic Fish & Chips.
London Eye is Europe's tallest observation wheel. Here you'll get amazing views to Central London and the city's main Landmarks like the Big Ben and Westmister Palace
Harrods is one of the most famous and luxurious department store in London it dates back to the 1800s.
Pizza Express is a British pizza and italian food chain restaurant This restauant is in the affordable side for the area and a classic for the locals.
Contemporary European cuisine with Michelin-starred quality. Make sure to make a reservation ahead of time. The head chef is Gordon Ramsay.
A 900-year-old castle that houses the crown jewels and armours. It was also a prision that holded many famous and infamous prisoners.
What was a small open-air fruit-and-vegetable market in 1654 is now a world-class shopping and dining destination.
A garden located on a skyscraper in London is free to visit and you'll get a 360 degree view of London!
Visit the first national public museum in the world founded in 1753. This museum holds over eight million objects documenting human culture from its beginnings.
The underground bunker that Prime Minister Winston Churchill and his war cabinet used to shelter from bomb raids and plottheir plans during World War II.
